titleStmt.title: Good nevves for the King of Bohemia? or, A certaine relation of the last and great ouerthrow, giuen by the Duke of Brunswicke to the Bishop of Cullen, and Duke of Bauariaes forces wherein was rumored, that Brunswicke was slaine. With the proceedings of Count Mansfield, since his last comming into the Palatinate, and since the Emperours ambassadour came into England, with other accidents, both in the Palatinate, and else-where. Sent of purpose by a person of account the eight day of April, and now published the seuenteenth 1622.

titleStmt.title: Good nevves for the King of Bohemia? or, A certaine relation of the last and great ouerthrow, giuen by the Duke of Brunswicke to the Bishop of Cullen, and Duke of Bauariaes forces wherein was rumored, that Brunswicke was slaine. With the proceedings of Count Mansfield, since his last comming into the Palatinate, and since the Emperours ambassadour came into England, with other accidents, both in the Palatinate, and else-where. Sent of purpose by a person of account the eight day of April, and now published the seuenteenth 1622.

notesStmt.note: Variant 1: title page has a colon instead of a question mark after "Bohemia". Variant 2: p. 28 correctly numbered.
Identified as STC 11354 on UMI microfilm.
Reproduction of the original in the Henry E. Huntington Library and Art Gallery.

projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

keywords.term: Thirty Years' War, 1618-1648 -- Early works to 1800.

div.p: GOOD NEWES FOR THE KING OF BOHEMIA?
OR; A Certaine Relation of the la≈øt and great Ouerthrow, giuen by the Duke of Brun≈øwicke to the Bi≈øhop of Cullen, and Duke of Bauariaes Forces; wherein was rumored, that Brun≈øwicke was ≈ølaine.

With The Proceedings of Count Mansfield, ≈øince his la≈øt comming into the Palatinate, and ≈øince the Emperours Amba≈ø≈øadour came into England, with other Accidents, both in the Palatinate, and el≈øe-where.
Sent of purpo≈øe by a per≈øon of account the eight day of Aprill, and now publi≈øhed the ≈øeuenteenth 1622.
Printed. 1622.

div.head: A RELATION of the Duke of Brun≈øwickes and Mansfields proceedings again≈øt the enemies Forces in the Palatinate.
div.p: BEcau≈øe I ≈øee, that the generall Currantos coming weekely ouer, haue rather ≈øtifled their owne credites, then giuen ≈øatisfaction vnto the world; and that yet men throng as fa≈øt to heare Newes, as they beyond the Seas throng ouer, and huddle together all manner of things to plea≈øe the people, both here and el≈øe-where; I could not chu≈øe but take pitty of their longings and de≈øires, that are truly affectionate to Religion, and the Cau≈øe of the Palatinate, and ≈øo expo≈øe vnto thee, who≈øoeuer thou art, this Relation of credite, which came to my hands the twelfth of Aprill, wherein you ≈øhall ≈øee a mode≈øt declaration of the affaires of Germany, and the tumultuous proceedings of ≈øuch Princes, as either wi≈øh well to the King of Bohemia, or ≈øuppo≈øe them≈øelues wronged by the Emperours imperiou≈øne≈ø≈øe, and Bauariaes ambitious ha≈øtine≈ø≈øe to v≈øurpe anothers inheritance, and ≈øo I fall to the matter, as I finde it thus written.

I will not trouble you, my ≈øelfe, nor contrarious humors; yea ≈øuch poore Papi≈øticall Newes-mongers, that will haue Sluce lo≈øt, and Brun≈øwicke ≈ølaine before euer they were in danger, with former repetitions of matters already publi≈øhed, nor once di≈øpute of the motiues, cau≈øes, effects, alterations, or any other circum≈øtances of the warres, eyther in Bohemia, or the Palatinate, but come roundly to the pre≈øent bu≈øine≈ø≈øe, and tell you what is now a doing, and what is likely to follow.

Euer ≈øince the Duke of Saxony beganne to repine at Bauariaes intru≈øion into the honour of the≈øe actions, and the Emperour ≈øeemed partially affected to his ≈øeruice, many Princes mi≈øliked the ≈øame, and by way of commi≈øeration thought it too much, that the King of Bohemia ≈øhould be vtterly ouerthrowne; and therefore, as you haue participated out of diuers Di≈øcour≈øes, they haue recollected them≈øelues, and thus proceeded toward his reliefe and ≈øupportation: whereas it hath beene fir≈øt generally reported, that Hungaria is reduced to the Emperours iuri≈ødiction, and that a League of Amitie hath beene contracted betweene him, and Bethelem Gabor; there is no ≈øuch matter, but rather the contrary. For the Prince of Tran≈øiluania calling the King of Bohemia Go≈ø≈øip, by rea≈øon he had chri≈øtned him a childe; hath prote≈øted neuer to for≈øake him, till he ≈øee him one way or another re-e≈øtabli≈øhed: Indeed I mu≈øt confe≈ø≈øe he hath ab≈øtained from crowning him≈øelfe king of Hungarie, vpon a certaine vow, he would neuer be inue≈øted, till the Spani≈øh garri≈øons and Emperors forces were put out of Rub, Camora & other places: yea till Pre≈øhurgh
it ≈øelfe were taken and cleered.

Secondly, the Marque≈ø≈øe of Ieggendorff keeping the fields and villages of Morauia for the v≈øe of the King of Bohemia cleane contrary to the feare and di≈øtre≈ø≈øe he hath bene put in by the Emperours forces, hath giuen him ≈øeuerall defeates, and approoued him≈øelfe a faithfull friend and ≈øeruitor.

Thirdly, the repinings of Prague, and ≈øome other townes, which are ≈øtill vnder the King of Bohemiaes protection haue bene greater again≈øt the Emperour and his forces of late dayes, then euer before.

Fourthly, the Duke of Wittenberg, ≈øcarce named in other Relations, hauing mu≈øtered ≈øome forces for the defence of his Countrey, and commaunded by the Emperour to vnite them to Bauaria, hath an≈øwered plainely, That as they are mu≈øtered by the aduice of his Coun≈øell and Lords, they are likewi≈øe to be di≈øpo≈øed by them, who neuer had occa≈øion of vnkindnes with the Palatine, and therefore will not now beginne.

Fiftly, the Princes of the Vnion perceiuing what a fearefull thing it is to let an enemy ≈øet footing in an others Countrey, e≈øpecially to fortifie him≈øelfe, as the Spaniard hath done in the Palatinate, are generall repiners at their owne fir≈øt ≈ølackene≈ø≈øe, and ≈øo re≈øolue to recouer their much di≈øtre≈ø≈øed honours by ≈øome new and glorious attempts in behalfe of their friend and confederate.

Sixtly, the Marque≈ø≈øe of Boden, and Lant≈øgraue of He≈ø≈øe, ≈øtanding hitherto, as it were, at a ≈øtay, though they euer had good harts, wil now draw their friend together, and be ≈øeene in the field.

Seuenthly, the Duke of Brun≈øwicke comming but fir≈øt into the Low countries, to ≈øalute the Queene of Bohemia at the Hage, offered them his ≈øeruice, and was not onely accepted, but ≈øupplied with men and money by the Sluces, and ≈øo went directly into We≈øtphalia, and by degrees like a ball of ≈ønow waxed bigger and bigger, & increa≈øed his forces, ≈øo that he attempted the Dioces of Cullen, & proceeded in many glorioue actions which you haue heard of, and which haue indeed made him renowned ouer the world.

La≈øt of all, Count Mansfield though ≈øome vnkindne≈ø≈øe at the fir≈øt pa≈ø≈øed between the Prince of Anhalt, and him, and all for the loue of the King of Bohemia: hath yet pro≈øpered ≈øo well, that he came round about the countries, & performed ≈øuch actions of admirations, that there are few kingdomes of Europe, which haue not bin filled with the relations of his proceedings, and euer memorable exploites, ≈øo that he hath reduced diuers Prouinces vnder his obedience, and now ≈øtands like a worke impregnable with a mighty army and mo≈øt willing heart to ≈øet forward the king of Bohemiaes de≈øignes.

The≈øe things are in the general thus ≈øet downe to ≈øhew you the cau≈øe, why the Emperor without controuer≈øie is weary of the warre, and ≈øu≈øpects that his friends wil neuer be able to with≈øtand ≈øo great forces & men exa≈øperated euery where again≈øt him, not ≈øo much for his owne cau≈øe, and great ≈øpirit in maintaining his honour & renowne, as hearkening to the Sirens ≈øongs of the Ie≈øuites, who in trueth care neyther for him, nor any Prince what≈øoeuer, nor for the ≈ølaughter of the people, di≈øturbance of their gouernments,
deua≈øtation of their countries, and vtter ≈øubuer≈øion of their quietnes, but for their owne ends & ≈øuperintendency euen ouer the Pope him≈øelf: whereupon he hath wi≈øely fore≈øeene greater mi≈øchiefes, & ≈øo doth politikely goe about to preuent the ≈øame by ≈øending an Amba≈ø≈øador into England for pacification (if it may be) of the≈øe troubles; but of this no more, til Time produce a fairer birth, & make knowne the ≈øucce≈ø≈øe of that Emba≈ø≈øie, with all other things depending.

I will now go forward to the bu≈øine≈ø≈øe in hand, which depends on the actions of the Duke of Brun≈øwicke, and Count Mansfield, who haue beene in pre≈øent imployment, euen ≈øince the Emperors Amba≈ø≈øadour went into England, and mo≈øt wonderfully ≈øet forward the King of Bohemiaes affaires, ≈øo that as far as men may be confident of worldly computation, ther is great hope of recouery, & turning of fortunes wheele, that he may be brought at la≈øt to the toppe, which hath ≈øo long beene kept with his head downeward: ≈øo that to make the matter more per≈øpicuous, I mu≈øt ≈øay with the Poet; arma viro≈øqne cuno, and tell you fir≈øt, what the Duke of Brun≈øwicke hath done, & next, how Count Mansfield hath proceeded.

Concerning Brun≈øwicke he hath long ≈øince bin in po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of Patter-horne, We≈øtphalia, and the Bi≈øhopricke of Cullen, wherein his progre≈ø≈øes haue had wonderfull ≈øucce≈ø≈øe, as by the preuailing in many skirmi≈øhes may appeare, ≈øo that the Bi≈øhop of Cullen being the duke of Bauariaes brother, hath diuers times aduerti≈øed the Emperor and the re≈øt of his friends, what di≈øtre≈ø≈øe he hath bene in, and is likely to endure, if he
be not better releeued, whereupon many by Bauariaes appoyntment haue come to his a≈ø≈øi≈øtance, namely Mon≈øieur Iilley, Gonzales; another Prince of Anhalt and the Gouernor of Gulick, all which haue ≈øundry times skirmi≈øhed with the Duke of Brun≈øwicke, and as you haue heard in as ≈øundry Relations could neuer boa≈øt of preuailing, no not of equality in their encounters, but departed ≈øtil with lo≈ø≈øe on their ≈øide, while the≈øe skirmi≈øhes had their ≈øeuerall pa≈ø≈øages; Newes came vnto him of the King of Bohemiaes departure from the Hage ≈øecretly in the company of ≈øir Francis Nether≈øoll, and ≈øir Charles Morgane, two Engli≈øh Knights, and eight other: ≈øome tolde him, that all his tents, armour and proui≈øion of the warre were ≈øhipped at Enchy≈øen to goe to Bream, or ≈øome other rendezuous nearer to him≈øelfe, and the places he meant to goe vnto; ≈øome di≈øcour≈øed of diuer≈øe men of warre which attended him, as though hee re≈øolued for Denmarke, but others ≈øeemed to vnder≈øtand the truth indeed, and a≈ø≈øured him he was gone di≈øgui≈øed from Calis to Sedan, to vi≈øite the old duke of Bolloigne, and there to acquaint Count Mansfield with his intent, and purpo≈øes, and receiue from him and ≈øir Horatio Vere, a true Certificate of the e≈øtate of the Palatinate, and the army, and ≈øo either to ex≈øpect a Conuoy to meete with Count Mansfield, or march with the whole army into ≈øom other country.

When the Duke of Brun≈øwicke heard of this, he forthwith be≈øtirred him≈øelfe, and ≈øet his actions on their be≈øt feete, that hee might be ready to attend the King of Bohemia where≈øoeuer hee went; and thus he preuailed in many ≈øeuerall encounters tooke
diuers pri≈øoners, ran≈øackt Patterborne, and We≈øtphalia, marched as farre as Sip≈øtate, ≈øackt 8 or 9 townes, battered diuers ca≈øtles and forts, and al ouer put the Papi≈øts in a generall feare, e≈øpecially the Ie≈øuites, whom of all others he hated, and of whom hee was ≈øome way reuenged: for they will haue him thus to proceed again≈øt them in two ≈øeuerall places.

Fir≈øt, while he was re≈øident in Mun≈øterland, and had according to the chaunce of warre, and cu≈øtome of Souldiers, pillaged the Villages, and ≈øpoyled the Inhabitants, two ≈øeuerall Ie≈øuites ≈øpared for no inuectiues again≈øt him, but railed in their Sermons, & in euery Pulpit where they preached, mi≈ø-termed him wor≈øe then a tyrant, bloud-≈øucker, and traytor, thundering again≈øt him cur≈øes and damnation; yea cur≈øing all his partakers and enterpri≈øes, whereupon the Duke of Brun≈øwicke thus exa≈øperated, proiected how to be reuenged, and yet would faine do it without ≈øhedding of bloud; whereupon he ≈øent a me≈ø≈øenger for them, whom they denied, and added Elias prayers for fire from heauen to con≈øume the Captains of fifty: then he ≈øent certaine troups to ≈øurpri≈øe them, who tooke them in a manner of an Ambu≈øcado, and brought them before him; whereupon hee that was mo≈øt faulty, kneeled downe, and importuned him to pardon his offence, and ≈øaue his life: at which Brun≈øwicke ≈ømiled & an≈øwered; that his life would do him no good, but he would make ≈øome ≈øport with him to cheere his hart: & thus prouing inexorable, he commanded certaine officers to ≈øtrip him naked, & drop him all ouer with pitch and tarre, keeping him ≈øtil by a warm fire, that it might be moi≈øt vpon him, & then
„Äà1 page duplicate„Äâ
„Äà1 page duplicate„Äâ
they rowled him among feathers, till he was all ouer like ≈øome ≈øtrange foule, or mon≈øter of Affricke: then he had a halter put about his necke, and ≈øo was led round about the army: la≈øt of all, he was ≈øent to the Nunnery, where the dainty La≈ø≈øes had work enough to make him cleane, and picke off his feathers.

Another time after the ≈øurpri≈øing of a towne, in which were two Ie≈øuites more wealthy, then all the religious Friers in the ≈øame; he ≈øent certaine Officers vnto them, to inuite them to a Banquet, who though they were vnwilling to come, yet they dur≈øt not deny; and when they came, were ≈øo extraordinarily well v≈øed, that they beganne with iollity to commend his entertainment, and thought them≈øelues ≈øecure, becau≈øe of outward Curte≈øies: at la≈øt the Duke of Brun≈øwicke drank to them, and told them, that he was certified they had much money lying by them, which they put to no good v≈øes; therefore he would play the Banker for them, and put it out both more charitably and piou≈øly; and when they began to deny it, calling our Lady & the Saints to witnes, that they were abu≈øed and ≈ølandred, he ≈øware a great oathe, adding withall, as he wi≈øht the K. of Bohemia to thriue: he would flea them naked, & torture them with pin≈øors, if either they dallied with him, or tooke not a pre≈øent cour≈øe to ≈øatisfie him: whereupon ≈øeeing no remedy, they brought his Officers to their Cloi≈øters, and ≈øhewed their trea≈øure, which amounted vnto 100000. dollers, and this was the end of that bu≈øine≈ø≈øe: but be not deceiued in this Relation about precedencie of time, as though this were newly done.

For it was the beginning of March la≈øt, and might haue bin ranked with his other actions, but that I ≈øuppo≈øe it came not within the reaches of common fingers, or dayly Corantos, and ≈øo I proceed to his la≈øt bu≈øine≈ø≈øe and encounters, which made way to a fal≈øe reports of his death. You haue many times heard that Cordua out of Cru≈ømacke, Generall of the army, which Spinola left in the Palatinate, and Mon≈øier Tilley from Bauaria, as he could be ≈øpared came to the a≈ø≈øi≈øtance of the Bi≈øhop of Collen Prince Elector, and receiued certaine ouerthrowes from Chri≈øtian Duke of Brun≈øwicke, who ≈øent his trophies of his ≈øpoyles to the King of Bohemia, as a rembrance of his ≈øeruice vnto her, whereupon euer ≈øince they haue watcht opportunity to be reuenged, and the Bi≈øhop hath mu≈øtered new forces, hauing ≈øupportation from the gouernours of Gulicke, We≈ø≈øell with certaine Burgonions and Wallons, who pre≈øently vnited them≈øelues to his owne ≈øubiects and people, and ≈øo made another ≈øtrong army which by the end of March was ready to march vnder the command of the yonger brother of the hou≈øe of Anholt, and here ≈øirnamed the Prince of Anholt: all the≈øe watched the Duke of Brun≈øwicke, and re≈øolued by ≈øome encounter or other to reintegrate their former credite and lo≈ø≈øes, and dayly followed him in the fieldes of Mun≈øter, We≈øtphalia, Paterborne, and other of the Bi≈øhop of Cullens Dioce≈ø≈øe, till at the la≈øt they found him neere the towne of Warebrough, where they re≈øolued to ≈øet vpon him: but yet they found him not ≈øo vnprouided, either as they conceiued, or wi≈øhed. For by the meanes of Duke Iohn of Sonderbergh, vnckle to the king of Denmarke,
a 1000. hor≈øe was newly come to him out of Ea≈øt-Free≈øland and North-Holland, vnder the command of Captain Iohn ‚Ä¢ hon≈øon of the Hage, with certaine other ≈øouldiers, who all prepared them≈øelues to fight with this new commer, the forenamd Prince of Anholt, who greedy of honour, and willing to rank him≈øelfe in the Catalogue of famous Captaines, came brauely vpon that battaile, wherein the Duke of Brun≈øwicke was fronted, nor was this ra≈øhly done, or as I may ≈øay in ≈øpleene and fury, but vpon great adui≈øe and deliberation. For be≈øides the Carbines that charged mo≈øt violently, the Battalion was flanked with Musketeers, who powred their ≈øhot into Brun≈øwickes battailes, and had the fortune to kill ≈øome of his men. For this was done ≈øo brauely, that his troopes were driuen to recoyle, and vpon that ≈øtaggering many thought he was ≈ølaine: for his hor≈øe was ≈øhot vnder him, and in that ama≈øe the people rumoured his death.

This was a hard beginning, and put the ≈øouldiers in a ≈øhrewd feare: For a whole Cornet of hor≈øe was ≈øhiuered, and Brun≈øwicke lay for the time vnder foot, but it la≈øted not long: for his youth and courage got the victory of a≈øtoni≈øhment, and vp he gets, and vp he mounts againe, fir≈øt cau≈øing the Captaines to to fill vp the roome with a body of pikes, who kept the enemies hor≈øe from comming too forward: then did he charge them with fre≈øh hor≈øe, and ere they could wheele about to bring their pi≈øtols bulleted he put them all to rowt, and ≈øo was quittance with them for their fir≈øt branery: but taking another body of pikes, and finding the enemies Battalion ≈øomewhat
thin of Musketeers, he ≈øet vpon them in ≈øuch a manner, that he powred into them at the lea≈øt three ≈øhot for one, and iu≈øt at the ≈øame time charged them to their very faces, and had a braue di≈øpatch, had not the ≈øecond time his hor≈øe beene ≈ølaine vnder him, and his ≈øecond fall, made his owne companie let fall their pikes, whereby they were daunted, and detained from further pro≈øecution, whereas que≈øtionle≈ø≈øe el≈øe they had made an end of that battaile, and that batttaile had ≈øure determined this controuer≈øie.

But vp hee gets againe, and vp hee mounts with courage and alacrity, and with that fury that hee ouerpre≈ø≈øed his enemies, and gaue ≈øuch example and encouragement to his Captaines, and ≈øouldiers, that in all the good Di≈øcipline of a skirmi≈øh) I cannot call it a battaile, becau≈øe the main battailes neuer came to fight) they ≈øeconded one another, that the ≈øhot kild three hundred, at three vollies, and the pikes trooped, as it were, to make the more ha≈øt to re≈øcue their braue Generall, who thus animated, ≈øet tho≈øe hor≈øe on worke that were neere≈øt and when the enemy began to ≈øhake, he pre≈ø≈øed them ≈øo violently, that many fell vnder his ≈øword, and by computation, this skirmi≈øh continued foure long houres, and ≈øurely had continued longer, if a braue Spani≈øh Captaine newly come out of Gulicke, had not brought vp certaine Hargubu≈øh on hor≈øebacke, and vnlookt for powred many ≈øhots into the pikes, which were ready to mingle with the Colonen≈øes, and at appoynt to end the bu≈øine≈ø≈øe, whereat the Duke of Brun≈øwicke enraged came ≈øo audaciou≈øly, that a Bullet grazed on his ≈øhoulder, and the
winde of many Bullets made him fall once againe from his hor≈øe, in≈øo much that a Wallon Captaine (as it was reported) ≈øtepped vnto him, ≈øuppo≈øing to take him pri≈øoner, but as he was lame in body, his bu≈øine≈ø≈øe ≈øucceeded as lamely: for to preuent the mi≈øchiefe, one Remigius a Dane oppo≈øed the lame Captaine, and in the ≈øight of the armies ≈ølue him outright, hauing thereby time to fetch vp Brun≈øwicks hor≈øe, and comfort to ≈øee him a liue, and vnhurt.

Thus is hee mounted the third time, and perceining the skirmi≈øh continue in ≈øome equalitie though the enemy had had the greater lo≈ø≈øe hee cau≈øed certaine field peeces of aduantage to be brought vp to the ≈øide of an hill, and mounted them ≈øo neere, that they were effectuall to the vnframing of a whole body of pikes, vpon who≈øe di≈ø-vniting ≈øome fre≈øh companies came in and ≈øo played their parts, that well breathed hor≈øe couragiou≈øly gaue a new a≈ø≈øault, and being well ≈øeconded, all was as well ended: for here were ≈ølaine 5000. and 800. taken pri≈øoners. Be≈øides, Prince Anholt Generall of the Bauarian forces, who was al≈øo taken pri≈øoner by the worthy Commander the Duke of Brun≈øwicke: and the Bi≈øhop had notice of a greater ≈ølaughter, which made him ≈øomewhat ≈øad and afflicted, till vnder≈øtanding that Brun≈øwicke was ≈øhot, and had lo≈øt foure hundred men, hee was then cheered againe, and a noble Prelate and Prince of Germanie, imputed all to the chance of war, and to the decider of controuer≈øies: notwith≈øtanding this ≈øeeming ≈øhew of vndaunted
courage, he ≈øu≈øpected lea≈øt the great Citie of Collen, would animate the Souldiers to ≈øpoile, and make their approaches neerer and neerer, ≈øo hee retires him≈øelfe to a ≈øtrong Ca≈øtle of his owne, vnder≈øtanding that the Bi≈øhop of Spiers had remoued to Coplen, and re≈øolued to ≈øecure him≈øelfe within the ≈øtrength of the Ca≈øtle of Thermonsteno, as for the Bi≈øhop of Monts: it was told him he had leaue of the Duke of Loraine, or if you had rather the King of France, to keepe his Court in Mets, a ≈øtrong fortified Towne and frontier Citie, which in tho≈øe dayes held out again≈øt the Emperour, and is ≈øtill the bulwarke and fortre≈ø≈øe of Fraunce, and odly hold in Loraine to ≈øecure the Countrey.

This is that, which is written of the Duke of Brun≈øwicks proceedings, but would I had time to write more: For he is a worthy Gentleman, and re≈øolute Souldier, their lackes but ≈øome yeares to mature his iudgement, and bring the≈øe good beginnings to pro≈øperous ends, of which there is no doubt. For commonly forwards Springs, if to bitter and hard Fro≈øts doe not nip the buds, are not onely comforts for the time, but pre≈øagers of plentifull Harue≈øts: and thus much for Brun≈øwicks proceedings; now to the re≈øt, but e≈øpecially Count Mansfield.

2 Concerning the Earle of Mansfield and his ≈øtrong Army, many remarkable things are written, which as briefly as I can I will ≈øuccinctly abreuiate into the≈øe heads. 1. Fir≈øt, that vnder≈øtanding, that all the Catholick Bi≈øhops were fled, hee gari≈øoned
mo≈øt of Army in their ≈øtrong holds, and quartred them in the Villages, whereby as they ≈øay in England, they had Mini≈øtrels fare, meate, drinke, and money. 2. Secondly, that when he perceiued his Army to encrea≈øe, and now to be ≈øo ≈øtrong, that the Monarchs of Europe looke vpon him with repining eyes, as wondering to what purpo≈øe he taketh ≈øuch large ≈øteps ouer the Catholick Countries, he made a defence or Apologie, diuulging it in the French tongue, and deliuered the Po≈øt of England, Balam by name, one of them to carie ouer with him. 3. Thirdly, that vnder≈øtanding of the Duke of Brun≈øwicks conflicts, hee writ Letters of gratification, and not onely applauded his actions, but reque≈øted a certificate from his owne hands, who returned an≈øwere, how he had preuailed in many skirmi≈øhes: burnt We≈øterkotton, Erquetts, Amruth, one of the Ge≈øecks, Ruden, Vberhagen, and the Dio≈øarts hou≈øe of Werdell come from Lip≈øtat, wherein hee had like to haue beene betrayed with 25. Cornets of Horie, 6000. Foot, diuers Peeces of Ordnance, Fireworks, ≈øcaling Ladders, and many Pyoners: vpon a de≈øigne of importance out, he ≈øuddenly heard of the approach of the Bi≈øhops forces, and ≈øo was compelled to ≈øtay and augment his Army, for a more fiercer encounter: and that he had taken ≈øome pri≈øoners, and ≈øome Friers, who were ≈øo ob≈øtinate, that they cryed out vpon nothing but trea≈øon and rebellion. 4. Fourthly, that while hee was at Germe≈øhem, and retired to many places with his maine Armie, Sir Horace Vere writing for ≈øome ≈øupplies, hee
≈øent to Mainhem foure Regiments of foot, ≈øome money, and munition, be≈øides many ≈øuppliments of victuall, and other proui≈øion, whereof the Gari≈øon there ≈øtood in great neede. For in truth thus it was with the Engli≈øh Generall at this time, all the forces hee had were partly ≈øecured in Mainhem, Franckendale, and Heidelberg, partly Gari≈øoned in the Villages, and partly running vp and downe for ≈øorraging, and other proui≈øion: ≈øo that euery day in one place or other, hee was troubled with the Bauarians, and Mon≈øieurs Tillyes Alarums, who≈øe Souldiers might wel be called the Regiment Voluntes: For they neuer lay long quiet in a place, but had many imployments, as Bauaria vnder≈øtood of the Enemies proceedings, and Emperours plea≈øure, whereupon ≈øu≈øpecting what they might doe vpon aduantage, he ≈øent to Count Mansfield, and was ≈øupplied accordingly: For without controuer≈øie, he ca≈øt vp his accounts in this manner. That my Lord Chiche≈øter was long a comming with ≈øupply into the Palatinate, but leaue the care of that to the Maie≈øtie of England, & that if the Spaniards and Bauarians ≈øhould be remoued by way of rendition of the Palatinate, or coÃÑpo≈øition for a peace, yet God knowes what might happen ere the bu≈øine≈ø≈øe were fully e≈øtabli≈øhed, and the peace ab≈øolutely concluded vpon: wherefore to ≈øtrengthen him≈øelfe, and to be informed of the ≈øtate of all affaires, he writ to Count Mansfield as you haue heard, and had not onely ≈øupply, but Letters of comfort concerning his re≈øolution, to continue con≈øtant to the Prince
his Ma≈øter.

5. Fiftly, that as he had fortified Haggenaw, hee would come and be≈øiege Lodenburg, and ≈øo prepare if neede be again≈øt Oppenheim, all which hee meant to doe with the third part of his forces: For he was per≈øwaded if the wor≈øt came, no further ≈øupply would enter into the Palatinate, either from the Spaniard or Emperour, con≈øidering it was vnfurni≈øhed, and that Gonzules lay quiet, as if he had had a charge to fight no more. Befides wants ≈øo encrea≈øed, that the Countrey was not able to ≈øu≈øtaine an Army on any ≈øide. For the Engli≈øh were hardly driuen, and hardly releeued. Gonzales had beene put to the triall of eating his hor≈øes: Mon≈øieur Tilley perplexed with hunger & ≈øeuerall imployment, ≈øo that he had ≈øcarce 5000. men left, and they ≈øubiect to ≈øickne≈ø≈øe, and other encombrances. The Bauarians in the ≈øame predicarment vexed with ≈øickne≈ø≈øe and cold, although the Emperour had hetherto ≈øent many helpes, and renewed their decayed Souldiers: and the Townes, though the riuers brought in proui≈øion, becau≈øe the Country people were rea≈øonably payed, yet felt the ≈øcarcity: For victuals grew deere in the Market, and the Burgers were glad to keepe good order without ryot or exce≈ø≈øe: yea, in many places Officers were ≈øet, as ≈øuperui≈øours, that neither the rich engro≈ø≈øed the Corne, Wine, nor meat, nor the poore ≈øhould be ≈øtarued for want of nece≈ø≈øaries. The≈øe things con≈øidered, hee tooke the more care in comming forward, and pe≈øtring the Countrey with his forces to
no purpo≈øe, but in my con≈øcience made acquainted with the King of Bohemias retiring, he prepared to ≈øpeake with him, and ≈øo to attend to bring their bu≈øine≈ø≈øe to ≈øome perfection, as God ≈øhall giue way vnto the ≈øame.

6. Sixthly, that ≈øeeing he had vi≈øited Al≈øatia all this Winter, and was in a manner Ma≈øter of Leopaldus his Countrey, he would ≈øure keepe what hee had gotten, and therefore as the Spaniard had taught him, and led the way in the Palatinate, hee would fortifie the ≈øtronge≈øt places, and when all failed, put the King of Bohemia in many po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of Prouinces for his owne Palatinate, if not ≈øet the Crowne of Prague more firmely on his head, then ouer it was before.

7. Seuenthly, that ≈øeeing his endeuours had put him in a manner in po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of foure Imperiall Cities, namely, Haggenaw, Spires, Wormes, and Ments, and that hee had brought them to the di≈øbur≈øement of what money he li≈øted, he ≈øaw no rea≈øon to let ≈ølip ≈øuch opportunity, but either keepe them in awe by his Armies, or make v≈øe of their ≈øeuerall Countries, to recompence the King of Bohemiahs lo≈ø≈øes, vntill a better time approach of better booty, which no doubt was now breaking out with the day to ≈øhew, that the Sunne of glory was ready to come out of his Chamber, to di≈øpell and bani≈øh away the contagious vapours of former trouble and di≈øcomforts.

8. Eighthly, that when the Emperour, or Duke of Bauaria, for the Emperour, by the aduice
of the Bi≈øhop of Collen had ≈øent vnto him to know, by what authority or in who≈øe name hee either rai≈øed, or kept together ≈øuch an Army: hee an≈øwered plainely and re≈øolutely, in Gods name, and the Kings, meaning the King of Bohemia: whereupon to expre≈ø≈øe him≈øelfe accordingly, he contriued this deui≈øe for his En≈øigne, or colours a radiant Sunne in an Azure field, di≈øpelling a many ≈ølender and vaporous clouds into a corner: thus hee not onely iu≈øtifies his actions, and emboldneth his Souldiers, but payeth his Army, and hath an orderly Trea≈øurer for their monethly entertainment, according to the preyes and ≈øpoiles they take: yea, to order his bu≈øine≈ø≈øe the better, he is now coyning thou≈øands of Rikes dollers with this deuice, an arme comming out of a cloud, holding a ≈øword poynant vpward, with a Ie≈øuites Cap pierc'd through: the Motto round about, Amicus dei omnibus ≈øuis inimicis inimicus. 9. Ninthly, that although many Friers and other Preachers v≈øed as many fearefull inuectiues again≈øt the Warre, the cau≈øes, the Authors, and effects, ≈øhewing plainly, it was a cur≈øe of God where≈øoeuer it lighted: yet did he giue way vnto the Sun, as if hee were willing to confe≈ø≈øe as much, intimating by many of his ≈øpeeches, that the Emperour, though he had wrong done him fir≈øt by the Proge ‚Ä¢
≈øes: yet tooke a wrong cour≈øe to inflict the King of Bohemians children, with the lo≈ø≈øe of their inheritance for their Fathers fault: as for their Father, many a Chri≈øtian heart did thinke it reuenge ≈øufficient to haue Prague ≈øurrendred, and to ≈øee the Palatine
di≈øappointed of the Kingdome, in which hee was crowned and inue≈øted: but ≈øtill to haue his Countrey deua≈øted, the territories depopulated, the Cities terrified with Souldiers: the Vines ≈øpoiled, the Woods cut downe, the cattell caried away, and all things ≈øubiect to the robberies of Souldiers, was too grieuous a reuenge, and vnmea≈øurable inflicting: yet this was not all neither. For be≈øides the bringing in of ≈øtrange Nations, and a ≈øtrange Religion to a religious Countrey, he had by way of donation, enfeoffed another with the ≈øame, not remembring, what eternall hate might grow hereafter betweene the≈øe two families, when peraduenture all the power of Au≈øtria, nor the Empire ≈øhould not reconcile them, which things orderly con≈øidered with many other dangerous to be publi≈øhed in a triuiall or common di≈øcour≈øe, made his actions the more iu≈øtifiable, con≈øidering the proceedings were ≈øo terrible, and although the Ie≈øuites aymed at him in their Sermons, as the Author of tho≈øe fearefull effects, and prodigious calamities, which the be≈øt Warre mu≈øt procure: yet all the world knowes the Spaniards were po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øours of the one ≈øide, and Bauaria was entred in the other, before euer he ≈øet footing therein, or tooke this cour≈øe of the Warres diuer≈øion, which by Gods grace and fauour, who ≈øet him on worke, hee would pro≈øecute as long as life la≈øted, or the King of Bohemias bu≈øine≈ø≈øe hung in ≈øu≈øpence.

10. Tenthly, that ≈øeeing the Duke of Bauaria hath fini≈øhed the bridge ouer the Neckar, and cau≈øed
diuers Wagons to come that way already with Corne and other proui≈øion, and that Mon≈øieur Tilley quartereth him≈øelfe neere Heidelberg, as though he meant to be≈øiege the ≈øame, or at lea≈øt tarry the time, till Bauarias forces be renewed, that ioyning together, they may performe their worke effectually, whereby it is ≈øo giuen out in England, and many are credulous of ≈øuch an impo≈ø≈øibility: he is re≈øolued to ≈øhew them no fauour, where≈øoeuer hee come: but as hee hath vi≈øited Laudenburg, and the ≈øtrong Ca≈øtle of Magdenburg, belonging to the Bi≈øhoprick of Spires, he will al≈øo come to Be≈øsing, and the Marque≈ø≈øe of Dan≈øtarrats Countrey, who was euer an Enemy to the Princes of the Vnion: for feare whereof the people haue already vnfurni≈øht their fields of their Cattle, and caried their goods into the ≈øtronge≈øt holds, at which Count Mansfield ≈ømiles to thinke, that poore Ca≈øtles & Forts ≈øhould ≈øecure them, when ≈øo many Cities and wel fortified places haue ≈øubmitted to his mercy, and made their attonement with him, yea the other day the Catholicks about Spiers and Wormes, ≈øeeing the good behauiour of his Souldiers, that they neither raui≈øhed women, nor murthered men, but onely tooke the pilledge of the Countrey, rifled the hou≈øes, the common cu≈øtome, and faire≈øt cour≈øe of a conquering Army, condi≈øcended, and by a generall con≈øent agreed to allow him 3000. mea≈øures of Corne, 200. Fats of Wine, and 60000. Florines, which though he did not accept of, as a full ≈øatisfaction to his demaunds, yet did hee take in
good part for the pre≈øent, and knew that if nece≈ø≈øity ≈øhould occa≈øion, they would be drawne to a further compo≈øition and disbur≈øement.

Thus for the time he de≈øi≈øted from vrging them to more then they were willng to graunt, con≈øidering he had formerly drawne great ≈øummes of money out of their Trea≈øuries: whereupon he proceeded to vi≈øite other Countries, and therein onely to take an oath of the Inhabitants of loyalty and fidelity to the King of Bohemia, and ≈øeruice and attendancie to him≈øelfe, and ≈øo he pa≈ø≈øed to the other ≈øide of the Rhine into the Countries of Didi≈øhene and Anoth, where the people ≈øeemed to wi≈øh well vnto the King of Bohemia, and very willingly tooke their Oath: then pa≈ø≈øed hee to the Graue of Louen≈øteins Countrey, which lyeth within the Bi≈øhopricke of Spires, and taking the ≈øame Oath of the inhabitants, he quietly receiued ≈øuch proui≈øion and money, as they would willingly ≈øpare: heere hee receiued newes that Mon≈øieur Tilly had brought his Ordinance, or Artillery to a place called Hu≈øcharen, as if he meant to goe to Heidelbergh indeed, but he let him alone, as re≈øoluing, that though he had power to his will, yet hee ≈øhould not attempt any enterpri≈øe of worth and moment, without interception: but a≈ø≈øured, that neither Bauaria could proceed in any ≈øuch de≈øigne, nor dur≈øt he lying ≈øo neare, but let them alone, till he had further directions from him, whoÃÑ he longs to ≈øpeake withall; ≈øo that in my Con≈øcience when that oportunity ≈øhal pre≈øent her hairy ≈øoretop vnto him, he will onely march through the
Palatinate into Bauaria's owne Countrey, and either make him looke to a new bu≈øines, or inrich his Army with the ≈øpoyle, that hee may be the better prouided to pa≈ø≈øe into Bohemia it ≈øelfe.

11. Eleauenthly, though he heard, that Don Cordua in per≈øon was ri≈øen from the Towne of Cru≈ønach to goe to Openhem, and fortifie the Bridge with Sconces to hinder all pa≈ø≈øengers, but ≈øuch, whom the Court of Guard ≈øhall licen≈øe: yet when he ≈øaw he ≈ølacked the ≈øame, hee conceiued he had ≈øome ≈øpeciall charge to proceed no further again≈øt the Engli≈øh, till the Emperours Amba≈ø≈øador were returned, and they knew what to tru≈øt vnto from England: So that one way hee found the people glad, that there was any glimmering light of Peace toward, and another way feared it would be a barre vnto his De≈øignes, if the King of Bohemia ≈øhould by any meanes be ouer-ruled, or per≈øwaded to ea≈øie Condition, and tractates of Friend≈øhip: but re≈øolued not to be di≈øturbed with conceit, or meditation of ≈øuch bu≈øines, which yet hung in ≈øu≈øpence, or were Coniecturall, he pre≈øently put him≈øelfe into Action, and ouerlooked his Fortifications and places, wherein he had Garri≈øon'd his Souldiers, and ≈øet vp his re≈øt to attend the good houre of further pro≈øecutions.

12. Twelthly, it was ≈øomewhat vnplea≈øing vnto him, that his Forces had layne ≈øo long before the Ca≈øtle of M ‚Ä¢ gdenburg, and ≈øpent as hee thought ≈øo much time to his di≈øgrace, and hindring his other de≈øignes, whereupon he went thither in per≈øon and
tooke away all meanes from them of ≈øuccor and reliefe, which when they perceiued, and were now debarred from former ≈øupportation, being old Soldiers and of great experience, they came to capitulate the matter, and ≈øurrendred the place vpon Condition to ≈øaue their liues, and depart with Bag and baggage, which they did without Colours di≈øplayed, or any ≈øhow of a Souldier; by which occa≈øion Count Mansfield tooke po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of the ≈øame, and found therein more wealth, then either he had at Spiers or Wormes: Thus did he preuaile in his action, and is now Lord of many Countries & holds, attending the good houre of the King of Bohemia's comming to him, or ≈øending for him: and ≈øo leaue him to the glory and in the fulnes of ioy, for this la≈øt good ≈øucce≈ø≈øe, which hath made him more confident & re≈øolute to ouer≈øway nicer exceptions, and goe forward in his pretences, though as yet he hath not fully expre≈ø≈øed the ≈øame concerning particulars.

Hauing thus left Count Mansfield in ≈øecurity, full of wealth, Glory, and a≈ø≈øurance to bring his purpo≈øes to a happy period. Let vs now come to other matters, not yet impertinent though not altogether depending vpon the former: You haue heard I am ≈øure by many relations publi≈øhed long ≈øince, that Duke Leopoldus Lord of El≈øas and Al≈øatia, was in a manner driuen out of his Countrey by the Forces of Mansfield: yet prettily ≈øalued that wound with this cure, that he went into the Valtolina, as Generall for the King of Spaine, though in his hart he repined at ≈øuch an V≈øurpation, which was euer belonging
to the Gouernment of another Prince. For of late the Hou≈øe of Au≈øtria condi≈øcended, that Spaine ≈øhould haue the prerogatiue, as hee had the Forces and ≈øtronger hand to holde them clo≈øe to his Mightines and preuayling. Well? heere hee mu≈øtered Soldiers and tooke vp two Regements to ≈øupply other Armies, but in the mid≈øt of this iollity, as hee was running away with hopes of recouery or reuenge: the money which was promi≈øed him out of Spaine fayled, and he could neither goe forward in that bu≈øines, nor dur≈øt returne into his owne Countrey for feare of greater forces, or more violent oppo≈øition: But ≈øome report, that the Emperour ≈øent him word, that hee was willing to a generall Peace and for that purpo≈øe had ≈øent Count Siratzenburg into England as his Amba≈ø≈øador, and therfore there needed no ≈øuch ha≈øtines to giue any cau≈øe of ≈øu≈øpition, that hee meant not ≈øincerely as he profe≈ø≈øed: This treaty of Peace ≈øet all humors and di≈øpo≈øitions on worke, and the Prouinces were as it detayned between feare and gladnes, what would be the i≈ø≈øue of the ≈øame, as for the Grizons & Swi≈ø≈øe? they ≈øhewed Leopoldus a face of di≈øcontent euery way, and brought out olde Records, wherein the Kings of France were authentically ≈øworne to bee their Protectors, how euer now they ≈ølacked the ≈øame, and gaue way to anothers Greatnes, the like might be ≈øaid of the Palatinate, Cleue, and other bordering Prouinces vpon the Empire, and confines of Burgundy: but times are alterers of mens purpo≈øes, and Kingdomes are eaten out with contraries; & taught
to know a le≈ø≈øon of Humiliation, when the Lord of all Kingdomes will admit of other Stewards, then he fir≈øt placed: Thus Leopoldus mu≈øt be content to ≈øee another man in po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øioÃÑ of many of his Townes, and other Prouinces of the Bi≈øhops, a≈øwell as the Palatinate was at the ≈øame in≈øtant v≈øurped by ≈øtrangers, and had indeed too many Ma≈øters.

Among≈øt other hopes and helpes, that the King of Bohemia hath, the Marque≈ø≈øe of Ieggendorffe is not the lea≈øt. For hee mu≈øtreth Soldiers dayly both in Sile≈øia and Morauia, yea hath had ≈øupply out of Walachia: and at this houre is doubtfull, whether he ≈øhall entertaine the Tartars or no, who came both to him and Bethlem Gabor by thou≈øands, and re≈øolue to a≈ø≈øi≈øt them, if need be again≈øt the Emperour, ≈øo that there is a great feare in Pre≈ølaw and Gratz, Citties of Sile≈øia, what ≈øhall become of them, if any alteration happen: whereupon the Lords and States rai≈øe vp many Forces, fortifie their Citties, prouide men, money, and munition, ≈øtand at a ≈øtay for their ≈øubmi≈ø≈øion, and doe neither openly warrant the Emperour their ab≈øolute Obedience, nor priuately wi≈øh ill to the King of Bohemia's proceedings, with which kinde of neutrality the Emperor is ≈øo di≈øplea≈øed, that he imputes the fault to the Duke of Saxonies negligence, as vnder≈øtanding that many Souldiers of Saxony, haue bin licen≈øed to depart home, and the Duke him≈øelfe is weary of the Warre; notwith≈øtanding the≈øe proceedings, and that there is a re≈øtraint of the Soldiers fury and violent cu≈øtomes, whereby Prague and other places, reduced vnder the
Emperours gouernment, doe yet hope and looke after ≈øome order for their Religion, and profe≈ø≈øion of a good con≈øcience: yet doth the Bi≈øhop of Prague proceede mo≈øt violently and cruelly again≈øt the Prote≈øtants, and will not ≈øuffer them to profe≈ø≈øe publiquely either in Churches, or priuate hou≈øes, any thing again≈øt the Church of Rome, ≈øo that euery where the Inhabitants or di≈øcontented, and pray to God for the diuer≈øion of the≈øe mi≈øchiefes, that haue not onely dilacerated the peace of Europe, but broken the hearts of poore ≈øoules to heare God ≈øo prophaned, and euery man in his owne particular terrified. For how euer it is reported, that in Siletia, Lu≈øatia, and tho≈øe Countries, there ≈øhall be a pre≈øent a≈ø≈øembly at Ea≈øter of the Lords and States of the Prouinces, yet hath the Bi≈øhop of Newes followed the example of the great Bi≈øhop of Prague, and locked vp the Churches from the Prote≈øtants, and will not ≈øuffer the Burgers to make open profe≈ø≈øion of their con≈øciences; whereupon by way of petition they haue ≈øollicited the Duke of Saxony to con≈øider their poore e≈øtates, and how euer, the Emperour mu≈øt captiuate their bodies and goods; yet to giue them leaue to haue their ≈øoules free to be≈øtow vpon the God of all freedome, and ≈øaluation: to which hee not onely an≈øwered very graciou≈øly, but gaue way vnder hand to all their Prote≈øtant a≈ø≈øemblies, and religious meetings, ≈øo that there is hope and light appearing, that either the Duke of Saxony is and will be di≈øcontented with the Emperour, whereby the vehemencie of his proceedings
may be ≈ølacked, or that hee will ≈øuffer the Inhabitants to enioy their owne freedomes, and peace of con≈øcience, to which purpo≈øe they haue procured another Mediator, euen Duke Weymar of Saxony his owne kin≈øman, who hath not onely profe≈ø≈øed him≈øelfe a Prote≈øtant, but rai≈øed two thou≈øand foot, and fiue hundred hor≈øe to ioyne with the Duke of Brun≈øwick in his proceedings, not doubting very ≈øhortly to be partakers of his glory, as well as of his ≈øpoiles, and hardly gotten conque≈øts.

Thus are the pure and delicate waters of Europes peace troubled and bedirtied with the wanton flingings of cruell handes: For Warre you ≈øee hath throwne Blood and corrupted Carka≈ø≈øes into the Sunne: men haue followed one another with Death and reuenge, and ≈øo drenched their ≈øtincking feete: Women haue bathed their raui≈øhed bodies and left their pollution behinde them: Souldiers haue wa≈øhed their corrupted woundes, and all ≈øorts with one filth or other, haue ≈øought to damme vp the ≈øtreames, and make the currant (if it were po≈ø≈øible, vnpa≈ø≈øible) ≈øo that vnle≈ø≈øe the ≈øtirring waters get the vpper hand, all will be ≈øpoyled, and if it once come to a ≈øtanding poole, it will ≈øtinke and putrifie: but the ≈øame God, that ≈øent the Angell to quicken the poole of Shilo, that the di≈øea≈øed might be cured, the lame re≈øtored, the drop≈øie healed, the leprous clen≈øed, & all infection purged, wil when he ≈øees his time, performe the like for vs, by turning
the inundation another way, and making the Riuers runne ≈ømoothly within their own euen bankes, or el≈øe he will doe, as he did by the waters of Murah, or by the flood Iordan, which was preferred before the Springes Dama≈øius to heale Naaman the Sirian.

To which purpo≈øe, let all tho≈øe, who wi≈øh the Peace of Syon, and the building vp of the walles of Ieru≈øalem, bring Incen≈øe and Sacrifice to the Altar of the Temple, and there lift vp their handes and hearts, that it may be propitious, and the God of Heauen not only ≈øcent a ≈øweet ≈ømelling ≈øauour: but giue vs notice of accepting our Prayers, and reque≈øts, by ≈øeeing the Angell a≈øcend in the flame.
